title.narrative: Equality Through Legal Action

description.narrative: Equality Through Legal Action addresses discrimination and human rights violations in Lebanon based on immigration status, nationality, gender and sexuality. The intervention empowers victims to seek meaningful access to justice, while trying to bring about legal reform.

condition.narrative: Refrain from activities undermining political autonomy of a state; refrain from conduct that is prohibited under Dutch law, including sexual harassment; refrain from offering or accepting gifts or remuneration from third parties that could be interpreted as an illegal or corrupt practice; ensure that no funds are used to provide support to individuals or groups associated with terrorism, directly or indirectly.

title.narrative: Outcome 3: Improved capacity of justice actors in the justice chain to address discrimination and inequality and to ensure the human rights of targeted communities are respected

System of legal aid referrals, oversight and adherence to human rights of detainees from targeted communities at pilot police station is perceived by users (police and detainees) as reducing discrimination against detainees from targeted communities

comment.narrative: Percentage of users (police and detainees) interviewed who perceive pilot system as reducing discrimination

title.narrative: Output 1.5 Conduct focus-group discussions with members of targeted communities to understand inequality and discrimination from the perspective of the most vulnerable community members
Number of focus-group discussions held

comment.narrative:
4 FGDs were held with migrant domestic workers. The sessions took place on March 23 (two sessions) and April 10 (two sessions). A total of 30 participants, all women, participated in the focus groups, of the following nationalities: 7 Ethiopian, 3 Kenyan, 7 Sri Lankan, 3 Beninese, 2 Malagasy, 1 Togolese, 1 Cameroonian, 2 Ivorian and 4 Bangladeshi.
4 FGDs were held with members of the LGBTQI community. The sessions took place on February 17 (2 sessions) and February 23 (two sessions). A total of 26 participants took part in the discussions.
4 FGDs were held with members of the stateless community. The sessions took place online on March 5 (two sessions) and March 9 (2 sessions). A total of 30 stateless persons participated in the discussions (19 women and 11 men).

title.narrative: Output 1.4 Legal assistance and representation is provided by lawyers and paralegals to targeted community members
Number of individuals from targeted communities who receive legal representation

comment.narrative: Disaggregation by target community: Migrant domestic worker: 5 LGBTQI: 2 Stateless: 9

title.narrative: Number of individuals from targeted communities who receive legal assistance

comment.narrative: Disaggregation by type of assistance: Counselling: 46 cases Mediation: 39 cases Civil documentation: 10

title.narrative: Output 2.3 File strategic litigation cases and design and implement complementary strategic advocacy strategy
Number of strategic litigation cases filed in the Lebanese court system

comment.narrative: On October 8, 2020, LAW filed a criminal complaint before the first investigative judge in Baabda, Mount Lebanon, on behalf of the client, a 38-year-old former Ethiopian migrant domestic worker. LAW’s case argues slavery, slave trading, trafficking in persons, forced labour, deprivation of liberty, withholding personal documents, racial discrimination, gender discrimination and torture. The defendants are the client’s former sponsor (kafeel) and recruiter. This case constitutes the first request in Lebanon for a criminal investigation into the treatment of a migrant domestic worker by her sponsor and recruiter. On October 21, 2020, LAW presented the case to the public in an online panel discussion titled, “The Kafala System in Lebanon: How can we obtain dignity and rights for migrant domestic workers.”

title.narrative: Output 1.1 Establish networks of the targeted communities and understand their needs through outreach
Number of outreach visits held

comment.narrative:
Outreach meetings: 1. Conducted by Anti-Racism Movement for migrant domestic workers: Reached 36 women Details: 30/11/2020: 8 women (1 Sri Lanka, 1 Nepal, 1 Philippines, 3 Ethiopia, 1 Sierra Leone, 1 Nigeria) 2/12/2020: 7 women (6 Ethiopia, 1 Bangladesh) 3/12/2020: 9 women (5 Cameroon, 2 Benin, 1 Senegal, 1 Cote d’Ivoire) 4/12/2020: 12 women (12 Sri Lanka)
Conducted by Helem for LGBTQI community: Reached 28 persons Details: All held in February 2021 Gender disaggregation: 12 ciswomen, 8 cismen, 3 gender-fluid persons, 2 agender persons, 3 gender non-binary persons Nationality disaggregation: 17 Lebanese, 1 Palestinian, 7 Syrian, 1 Egyptian, 1 American, 1 Stateless
Conducted by LAW for stateless community: Reached 23 persons Details: 28/1/2021: 7 persons (5 Lebanese women, 2 Lebanese men) February - April 2021: 3 online outreach meetings reaching 16 persons (11 Lebanese women and 5 Lebanese men)

title.narrative: Output 1.2 Community leaders are capacity built to become advocates
Number of community members trained to become advocates

comment.narrative:
The first advocacy training was conducted on 24 April 2021 in Beirut, for migrant domestic workers. The training was attended by 17 women of the following nationalities: 2 Ethiopian, 2 Nepalese, 1 Sri Lankan, 3 Philippine, 2 Nigerian, 1 Ivorian, 1 Beninese and 5 Cameroonian.
A second training was held on 21 May 2021 in Beirut for the LGBTQI community. The training was attended by 11 persons (3 ciswomen, 6 cismen, 1 transgender, 1 gender-fluid; 5 Lebanese, 2 Syrian, 1 Palestinian, 1 Egyptian, 1 American, 1 Stateless)

comment.narrative: Disaggregation by target community: Migrant domestic worker: 175 LGBTQI: 51 Stateless: 34

title.narrative: Number of information sessions held
Output 2.2 Identify, research and compile strategic litigation case files
Number of strategic litigation case files compiled

comment.narrative: In April 2019, LAW received a call from an organisation working in the humanitarian field explaining the case of a 38-year-old migrant domestic worker from Ethiopia. LAW’s legal team compiled all relevant files related to the submission of this strategic litigation case. For this case, LAW had two options: 1) to approach a civil court to claim unpaid wages, or 2) to approach a criminal court with a complaint of human trafficking, slavery and forced labour. With the client’s consent, LAW decided to initiate a criminal lawsuit.

title.narrative: Number of legal opinions drafted
Outcome 2: Legal change reducing inequality and discrimination is precipitated through strategic litigation
Number of unjust laws or laws incompatible with Lebanon's human rights obligations challenged by strategic litigation
Outcome 1: Discrimination and inequality are addressed through the provision of quality legal aid to targeted communities
Percentage of beneficiaries of legal representation and assistance who report that it resulted in a beneficial outcome

Specific Objective: To address serious discrimination and human rights abuse and violations based on immigration status, nationality, gender or sexuality in Lebanon and empower victims and survivors to meaningfully participate in effective access to justice and legal change
Percentage of victims and survivors interviewed who receive legal information, assistance and/or representation report feeling empowered by their engagement with the project
Overall Objective: To achieve equality before the law, attitudinal change and legal redress for individuals and groups who are discriminated against in Lebanon
Legal change occurs in relation to the legal framework applied to migrant domestic workers, LGBTQI persons, statelessness or gender inequality
